unnormalised: The year was 1942. My grandfather, then a young man of 18, often spoke of those sweltering August days. He'd narrate stories of clandestine meetings held under the cover of darkness, fueled by chai and a burning desire for freedom. It was the Quit India Movement, and the air in Allahabad was thick with anticipation and fear. He’d tell me, in detail, about what happened on 08/08/1942, the day Gandhiji gave the call for "Do or Die."
normalised: The year was one thousand nine hundred and forty two. My grandfather, then a young man of eighteen, often spoke of those sweltering August days. He'd narrate stories of clandestine meetings held under the cover of darkness, fueled by chai and a burning desire for freedom. It was the Quit India Movement, and the air in Allahabad was thick with anticipation and fear. He’d tell me, in detail, about what happened on eighth August one thousand nine hundred and forty two, the day G-andhiji gave the call for "Do or Die."

unnormalised: Grandfather, R.K. Sharma, was a volunteer, distributing leaflets printed with revolutionary slogans. He recalled how the British authorities imposed curfews, and how the local constables patrolled the streets after 8 PM. The meetings were held in secret locations, often shifting to avoid detection. One such gathering was scheduled for 09/08/1942 at 6 PM near the banks of the Ganga. He vividly remembered the date because, as he put it, “that’s when the real trouble began."

One such gathering was scheduled for ninth August one thousand nine hundred and forty two at six P-M near the banks of the Ganga. He vividly remembered the date because, as he put it, “that’s when the real trouble began."

unnormalised: On 09/08/’42, the police raided the meeting place. Many were arrested, including some of his closest friends. Grandfather managed to escape, scrambling through narrow alleyways he knew like the back of his hand. He spoke of the bravery of the women, who fearlessly confronted the police, shielding the younger activists. He always mentioned one incident that happened around 11:00 AM that same day, where a group of women blocked a troop movement simply by sitting on the road.

unnormalised: The impact of 02/10/1869, Gandhiji's birthday, was always highlighted by my grandfather when describing the movement because it provided inspiration. He also mentioned the day of Jallianwala Bagh Massacre, 13/04/1919, to highlight the British brutality, to remind us what they fought against. He said that these dates were etched in everyone’s memory.

unnormalised: The movement ebbed and flowed, facing brutal repression. My grandfather recounted incidents from 1943 and 1944, mentioning the mass arrests of leaders and the clampdown on any form of dissent. He told how, even with independence seemingly a distant dream, the spirit of defiance remained unbroken. Then came the momentous day, etched in every Indian's heart.

unnormalised: He often repeated, "15/08/1947, beta, that's the day our shackles broke at midnight." He remembered it vividly - the celebrations, the tears, the euphoria. My Dadi said he didn't sleep for days, going around distributing sweets and singing patriotic songs until his voice was hoarse. He had waited for what felt like an eternity, and then, finally, India was free.

unnormalised: Decades later, as he sat on his veranda, sipping his evening chai, my grandfather would often reflect on those tumultuous years. He said that even though he played a small role, he was proud to have been part of something so significant. He instilled in me a deep respect for our nation's history and the sacrifices made to achieve independence. And every year, on 15th August, I remember his stories and the echoes of a nation's struggle for freedom. He left us on 26/01/2000, another significant day for India, The Republic Day. But his stories, and the lessons he taught, will forever remain etched in my heart.
